profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Paul E. Baran on August 21, 2008

did.head: Overview of the Collection
did.abstract: Artificial collection of genealogical material consisting of single items or small collections less than .25 cubic feet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Artificial collection of genealogical material consisting of single items or small collections.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Researchers should request these items by Accession number.
Some of these records are stored at an off-site facility and therefore may not be available on a same-day basis.

did.unittitle: Memoir of Col. Charles Burrall and other biographies; Coipied for John Dickinson Burrall, a lineal descendant of the sixth generation

scopecontent.p: Contents: Summary of Burrall lineage; Sketch of the life of Col. Charles Burrall written by himself when 80 years of age, from copy made 1829 by his granddaughter Mrs. Elna Rockwell Emerson, this copy made apparently by the latter's son or daughter, E.M. Emerson of Rockwood, Ill., Sept. 1861; Recollections of Col. Charles Burrall, Sr., by grandson Thomas D. Burrall (1786-1872) of Geneva, N.Y.; Some recollections of William Burrall, by his granddaughter Elisabeth B. Belden, South Canann, December 15, 1886; William Morgan Burrall (died South Canaan, November 21, 1856); William M. Burrall: Extract from lecture delivered before the Litchfield County Bar, April 13, 1870 by Charles F. Sedgewick, Esq.; Obituary of William P. Burrall, by Henry C. Robinson, in the Hartford Courant, March 4, 1784, clipping of same from newspaper; John Milton Burrall, 1834-1880 [and his son, John Dickinson Burrall, born 1880,] written by the latter's mother, Mary D[ickinson] Burrall, Richmond, Va., November 28, 1908; Extraneous material.

note.p: Transferred to Archives from general collection. Formerly catalogued as 929.2 B942.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found at
Related material may be found at
Related material may be found at [CSL call number History Reference Spec.Gen.File Catlin]

Louise Patten obituary; Patten family; Davis family; Pomeroy family; Holmes family; Cooke family; Washburn family; Torrey family; Torrey family (English); Burt family; Longmeadow: Lay-out of central street from Srpingfield to Enfield; Stebbins family; Colton family; Bliss family; Chapin family; Hale line; Miscellaneous papers.

note.p: Transferred to Archives from general collection. Formerly catalogued as 929.2 P277p.

did.unittitle: Historical statement...written for a family celebration in 1876 / by Newman Peck

bioghist.p: Newman Peck was born in 1795, son of Lament5 (Zebulon4, Samuel3, Saumuel2, Deacon Paul1 of Hartford). Zebulon, Lament, and Newman resided in Bristol; Newman removed to Wisconsin in 1841.

scopecontent.p: This statement includes some details about the family which do not appear in the section on Deacon Paul Peck in Ira B. Peck's "Genealogical History..." (1868), pages 367-389 #5, 24, 55, 131-139, 319-130, 605-612. Pages 18-365 of the statement is reminiscences of Peck's early days in Bristol, under the following headings: Schools, Churches, Amusements, Military, Temperance, Clocks, Whipping Post, Whigs and Tories, Witchcraft, Wagons, Physicians, Attorneys, Mineral, and Manufacturing.

note.p: Photostat copy from original manuscript owned by Miss Ellen Barnard Peck, of Bristol, loaned to the Connecticut State Library for photostating October 10, 1950 via Justice Newell Jennings.
Transferred to Archives from general collection. Formerly catalogued as 920 P336.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found at

bioghist.p: Charles Lyman Shaw was born February 7, 1842 in Plainfield, Mass. and died May 27, 1902 in Astoria, Long Island, N.Y.

note.p: Notebooks are numbered 1-8, 10-12, 14. There is one notebook with a missing front cover and thus unnumbered.

relatedmaterial.p: The at the University of Massachusetts Amherst contains one folder of Charles Lyman Shaw's writings, circa 1894.
